text:
Professional Experience
ACM-W Tech Fellowship (Winter 2026-Spring 2026)
Product Management and Software Engineering Fellow

Selected as a fellow in a two-quarter technical fellowship focused on end-to-end product development, integrating software engineering with product strategy to guide ideas from user discovery through prototyping, iteration, and minimum viable product (MVP) delivery.
Participate in a multidisciplinary team to architect, design, and implement a web application that helps users discover on- and off-campus study locations, incorporating AI-driven personalization to recommend spaces based on user preferences, needs, and usage patterns.
Apply product management frameworks and software development best practices across the full product lifecycle, while participating in technical and strategic workshops on product strategy, system design, and agile execution to drive measurable weekly progress.
Will develop and deliver a data-driven, stakeholder-focused final pitch presenting product vision, technical implementation, and market rationale to industry professionals, startup founders, and alumni, emphasizing impact, scalability, and feasibility.

Reinsurance Group of America (Summer 2025)
Business Architecture Intern

Contributed to migrating and modernizing legacy valuation systems onto enterprise data platforms (EDP), improving scalability, maintainability, and overall performance while ensuring new systems’ alignment with enterprise architecture standards.
Designed, developed, and optimized financial and operational reporting dashboards by transitioning from Tableau to Power BI, implementing DirectQuery for large datasets, enabling real-time insights, and improving decision-making efficiency across business units.
Optimized data pipelines through advanced Alteryx workflows, incorporating robust error handling, validation logic, automated quality checks, and seamless SQL and ETL integration to ensure high data integrity, reliability, and process efficiency in valuation reporting.
Collaborated cross-functionally with business strategy, analytics, and actuarial teams to streamline data workflows, standardize reporting logic, and strengthen the technical infrastructure supporting enterprise-wide data science initiatives and data products.

Northrop Grumman (Summer of 2024)
College Technical Intern

Re factored and optimized C++ simulation code within AFSIM to enhance radar search algorithms, improving rasterization efficiency and increasing area coverage by ~30% through parameter tuning, algorithmic redesign, and advanced performance optimization techniques.
Conducted radar performance analysis using Python, deriving novel spatial coverage metrics not previously available, performing multivariate analysis, and identifying critical factors influencing search effectiveness to inform algorithmic enhancements.
Designed and implemented a digital controller prototype integrating real-time weather data APIs, modeling dynamic pre-flight environmental conditions, generating interactive visualizations, and supporting data-driven pilot decision-making.
Developed official technical documentation and standardized methodologies based on research of radar search strategies and AFSIM simulations, defining quantitative metrics for radar accuracy and efficiency, and detailing Python workflows for reproducible results.

UCLA Competitive Sports (2023-present)
General Manager

Check in intramural participants to their games and provide customer service to attendees and athletes.
Keep scores and times for games and help set up and tear down equipment and tents for events.

title: Claire Nabours
text:
Hi! I’m Claire Nabours and I’m a senior at the University of California, Los Angeles majoring in Statistics and Data Science. I am passionate about building data-driven products that create meaningful impact. At Northrop Grumman and Reinsurance Group of America, I applied Python, R, and SQL to solve complex technical problems while translating analytical insights into scalable solutions that support business decision-making. Through my Product Management and Software Engineering Fellowship, I have gained experience guiding products from user discovery to MVP delivery, aligning cross-functional teams, prioritizing features, and ensuring technical execution drives real-world outcomes. You can learn more about my work and product experience in my the porjects tab!

Education
Univerisity of California, Los Angeles (2022-2026)
B.S. in Statistics and Data Science


Skills:
Python, R, SQL, C++, Snowflake, Power BI, Tableau, Data Analysis, ETL, Simulation, Modeling, Optimization Methods, Neural Networks, Probability and Statistics, Experimental Design, Software Engineering, Cross-Functional Communication, MVP Delivery, and Agile Methodologies.

title: Factorial Approach to Assessing Nicotine and Caffeine’s Effects on Short-Term Cognitive Performance
text:
About This Report
This project utilized a 2^2 factorial experimental design with blocking to examine the short-term cognitive effects of nicotine and caffeine. The study measured changes in memory task performance among participants across treatment combinations, while controlling for age and time of day. Through statistical modeling, ANOVA analysis, and diagnostic checks, the report evaluates the main and interaction effects of the two stimulants. The goal of this work was to better understand how substances commonly consumed by students influence short-term memory performance and whether they interact in meaningful ways.
My Contributions
I helped run the experiment itself, ensuring treatments were administered properly and data collection was consistent across participants. I also played a role in designing the factorial experiment and explaining its structure, including the blocking factors of age and time of day. I also worked on verifying and interpreting the model assumptions and contributed to writing the discussion section, where we connected statistical results to broader implications for cognitive performance and student behavior.

title: Orders Regression Report
text:
About This Report
This project analyzed Amazon consumer survey data to predict monthly state-level sales using regression modeling techniques. We applied exploratory data analysis, transformations, and feature engineering to address skewness, categorical effects, and multicollinearity. Six models were developed and compared using five-fold cross-validation with RMSE as the evaluation metric. XGBoost achieved the best performance, highlighting the importance of nonlinear modeling in capturing complex consumer purchasing patterns.
My Contributions
I created the exploratory data analysis and data visualization, producing plots and summaries to guide preprocessing decisions. I contributed to the design of the preprocessing pipeline, including transformations and feature engineering. I also implemented and evaluated linear, ridge, and lasso regression models, comparing their performance to other approaches. In addition, I wrote the Exploratory Data Analysis and co-wrote the Preprocessing sections of the report and contributed to the Results and Discussion.

title: The Masked Miles Project
text:
About This Report
Masked Miles is a digital humanities project that examines how COVID-19 reshaped travel in the United States, focusing on California and Florida. By comparing state-level policies, mobility trends, and case rates, the project reveals how contrasting responses to the pandemic influenced travel behaviors, tourism, and public health outcomes—highlighting the human story behind pandemic travel.
My Contributions
I served as the project manager, coordinating workflow and deadlines to ensure smooth collaboration. I also explored and analyzed the data, created visualizations to support the narrative, and contributed to writing the narrative itself. In addition, I worked on the design and development of the website, shaping both the overall look and the main content pages.

title: Election Winner Classification Report
text:
About This Report
The Election Winner Classification Report is a project that investigates the use of predictive modeling for classification of U.S. election outcomes. By applying models such as logistic regression, decision trees, and ensemble methods, the project evaluates how demographic, political, and socioeconomic features contribute to predicting winners. The report provides insight into which variables most strongly influence results.
My Contributions
I focused on developing and optimizing the models for this project. Specifically, I built logistic regression, linear discriminant analysis, quadratic discriminant analysis, and support vector machine models, incorporating preprocessing techniques and Bayesian optimization to improve performance. In addition, I conducted the exploratory data analysis (EDA), creating visualizations and statistical summaries to uncover trends in the dataset and guide model design. I also contributed to the final report by writing the EDA and model development sections, ensuring the methodology and findings were clearly communicated.

title: Gender Attitudes And Demographics’ effects on Female Leadership
text:
About This Report
This project investigated how demographics and attitudes toward women influence voting behavior, with a focus on support for women in public office and political party preference. Using multiple linear regression, logistic regression, and random forest models, the study examined the relative importance of attitudinal versus demographic predictors. Exploratory data analysis, variable importance plots, and refined modeling approaches were used to identify key factors influencing public office support and political alignment, while assessing model assumptions and addressing potential overfitting. The goal was to understand the role of gender attitudes in shaping political behavior and to provide insights into promoting equitable perceptions of leadership.
My Contributions
I contributed to writing the introduction, abstract, conclusion, and limitations and recommendations, ensuring clarity and cohesion across the report. I developed the model variables section, describing both demographic and attitudinal predictors, and worked on checking model assumptions and interpreting interaction effects to prevent overfitting. These efforts helped frame the project’s methodology, interpret statistical findings, and connect results to broader implications for support of women in leadership and political behavior.

title: Intersection of Arts and Sciences Blog
text:
About This Report
This blog was created as part of UCLA’s DESMA 9 course (Art, Science & Technology). It documents my weekly reflections, event write-ups, and projects that explore the intersections of art, science, and technology. Through it, I connected course concepts to real-world examples, exhibitions, and research while developing a personal voice in analyzing how creativity and innovation intersect across disciplines.
My Contributions
I researched, wrote, and designed all blog posts, focusing on connecting course material to real-world examples. My work included analyzing museum exhibits, lectures, and artistic movements, and presenting them through a personal and reflective lens. I also managed the overall structure and look of the blog to ensure it was clear and engaging.

title: Framing Food and Authority: A Social Media Analysis of Nutrition Influencers and Audience Reactions
text:
About This Report
Framing Food and Authority: A Social Media Analysis of Nutrition Influencers and Audience Reactions is a digital humanities research project. The project examines how nutrition influencers construct authority on social media, focusing on Twitter/X discourse surrounding Nina Teicholz. Using a mixed-methods approach that combines discourse analysis with computational techniques such as sentiment analysis, topic modeling, and social network analysis, the study explores how language, framing, and emotional appeals shape public responses to contested nutrition science.
My Contributions
I contributed with writing the Platform, Topic, and Selection Criteria, Findings, and Conclusion sections, synthesizing computational results with rhetorical analysis. I also assisted where possible with code development for data collection and analysis and helped edit the final report. Additionally, I created the project’s public website, translating academic findings into accessible content for a broader audience.
Link to Project Website
Food and Authority Website
